com.oracle.truffle.api.interop

Class Message

  • java.lang.Object
    • com.oracle.truffle.api.interop.Message

  • public abstract class Message
extends Object
    Inter-operability is based on sending messages. Standard messages are defined as as constants like Message.IS_NULL or factory methods in this class, but one can always define their own, specialized messages.
    Since:
    0.8 or earlier

    • Field Detail

      • READ

        public static final Message READ
        Message to read an object field. The target created for this message accepts (in addition to a receiver) a single argument identifying a field to read - e.g. either String or a Number - if access to an array at particular index is requested.

        If the object does not support the Message.READ message, an UnsupportedMessageException has to be thrown. If the object does not allow reading a property for a given identifier, an UnknownIdentifierException has to be thrown.

        The code that wants to send this message should use: 

         ForeignAccess.sendRead(
   Message.READ.Message.createNode(),  receiver, nameOfTheField
 );
        Where receiver is the foreign object to access and nameOfTheField is the name (or index) of its field.

        To achieve good performance it is essential to cache/keep reference to the created node.

        Since:
        0.8 or earlier

      • UNBOX

        public static final Message UNBOX
        Converts truffle value to Java primitive type. Primitive types are subclasses of Number, Boolean, Character and String. Before sending the Message.UNBOX message, it is desirable to send the Message.IS_BOXED one and verify that the object can really be unboxed.

        If the object does not support the Message.UNBOX message, an UnsupportedMessageException has to be thrown.

        To unbox an object, use: 

         ForeignAccess.sendUnbox(
   Message.UNBOX.Message.createNode(),  objectToUnbox
 );
        The returned value should be subclass of Number, Boolean, Character or String.

        To achieve good performance it is essential to cache/keep reference to the created node.

        Since:
        0.8 or earlier

      • WRITE

        public static final Message WRITE
        Message to write a field. The target created for this message accepts the object to modify as a receiver and two arguments. The first one identifies a field to read - e.g. either String or an Integer - if access to an array at particular index is requested. The second one is the value to assign to such field.

        If the object does not support the Message.WRITE message, an UnsupportedMessageException has to be thrown. If the object does not allow writing a property for a given identifier, an UnknownIdentifierException has to be thrown. If the provided value has an unsupported type and cannot be written, an UnsupportedTypeException has to be thrown.

        Use following style to construct field modification message: 

         ForeignAccess.sendWrite(
   Message.WRITE.Message.createNode(),  receiver, nameOfTheField, newValue
 );
        Where receiver is the foreign object to access, nameOfTheField is the name (or index) of its field and newValue is the value to assign to the receiver's field.

        To achieve good performance it is essential to cache/keep reference to the created node.

        Since:
        0.8 or earlier

      • IS_EXECUTABLE

        public static final Message IS_EXECUTABLE
        Message to check executability of a foreign object.

        Calling the target created for this message accepts no arguments and a single non-null receiver. The call should yield value of Boolean. Either Boolean.TRUE if the receiver can be executed (e.g. accepts Message.createExecute(int) message, or Boolean.FALSE otherwise. This is the way to send the IS_EXECUTABLE message: 

         Boolean canBeExecuted = (Boolean) ForeignAccess.sendIsExecutable(
   Message.IS_EXECUTABLE.Message.createNode(),  receiver
 );

        To achieve good performance it is essential to cache/keep reference to the created node.

        Since:
        0.8 or earlier

      • IS_NULL

        public static final Message IS_NULL
        Check for null message. The Truffle languages are suggested to have their own object representing null like values in their languages. For purposes of inter-operability it is essential to canonicalize such values from time to time - sending this message is a way to recognize such null representing values: 
         Boolean isNull = (Boolean) ForeignAccess.sendIsNull(
   Message.IS_NULL.Message.createNode(),  objectToCheckForNull
 );

        Calling the target created for this message should yield value of Boolean.

        To achieve good performance it is essential to cache/keep reference to the created node.

        Since:
        0.8 or earlier

      • HAS_SIZE

        public static final Message HAS_SIZE
        Message to check for having a size. If a TruffleObject indicates it has a size, it is expected it represents array-like structure and it also properly responds to Message.GET_SIZE message

        Calling the target created for this message should yield value of Boolean.

        Since:
        0.8 or earlier
        See Also:
        ForeignAccess.sendHasSize(com.oracle.truffle.api.nodes.Node, com.oracle.truffle.api.interop.TruffleObject)

      • GET_SIZE

        public static final Message GET_SIZE
        Getter of the size. If supported, this message has to return size of receiver's array like structure as an Integer. If the Message.HAS_SIZE message returns true implementations for Message.READ and Message.WRITE messages with Integer parameters from range 0 to GET_SIZE - 1 are required.

        Calling the target created for this message should yield value of Integer.

        If the object does not support the Message.GET_SIZE message, an UnsupportedMessageException has to be thrown.

        Since:
        0.8 or earlier
        See Also:
        ForeignAccess.sendGetSize(com.oracle.truffle.api.nodes.Node, com.oracle.truffle.api.interop.TruffleObject)

      • IS_BOXED

        public static final Message IS_BOXED
        Check for value being boxed. Can the foreign object be converted to one of the basic Java types? Many languages have a special representation for types like number, string, etc. To ensure inter-operability, these types should support unboxing - if they do, they should handle this message and return Boolean.TRUE. The way to check whether an object is boxed is: 
         Boolean isBoxed = (Boolean) ForeignAccess.sendIsBoxed(
   Message.IS_BOXED.Message.createNode(),  objectToCheck
 );
        Calling the target created for this message should yield value of Boolean. If the object responds with Boolean.TRUE, it is safe to continue by sending it Message.UNBOX message.
        Since:
        0.8 or earlier

      • KEYS

        public static final Message KEYS
        Obtains list of property names. Checks the properties of a foreign objects and obtains list of its property names. Those names can then be used in Message.READ and Message.WRITE messages to obtain/assign real values.

        The return value from using this message is another TruffleObject that responds to Message.HAS_SIZE message and its indexes 0 to Message.GET_SIZE - 1 contain String names of individual properties.

        Since:
        0.18

    • Constructor Detail

      • Message

        protected Message()
        One can define their own extended message by subclassing. The expectation is that the subclass will have public constructor and its Message.equals(java.lang.Object) and Message.hashCode() methods will operate on the class equivalence. Only then the subclass will work properly with Message.valueOf(java.lang.String) and Message.toString(com.oracle.truffle.api.interop.Message) methods.
        Since:
        0.8 or earlier

    • Method Detail

      • createExecute

        public static Message createExecute(int argumentsLength)
        Creates a non-object oriented execution message. In contrast to Message.createInvoke(int) messages, which are more suitable for dealing with object oriented style of programming, messages created by this method are more suitable for execution where one can explicitly control all passed in arguments.

        To inter-operate with a non-OOP language like C - for example to execute its function: 

         double add(double a, double b) {
   return a + b;
 }
        One can obtain reference to the add function (for example by importing it as a global symbol) and store it into variable addFunction. Then it's time to check the object is executable by sending it the Message.IS_EXECUTABLE message.

        If the object does not support the EXECUTE message, an UnsupportedMessageException has to be thrown. If the caller provides a wrong number of arguments, an ArityException has to be thrown. If one of the provided argument values has an unsupported type, an UnsupportedTypeException has to be thrown.

        Use following style to construct execution message: 

         ForeignAccess.sendExecute(
   Message.createExecute(2).Message.createNode(),  addFunction, valueOfA, valueOfB
 );
        The valueOfA and valueOfB should be double or Double or at least be unboxable to such type.

        One can use this method to talk to object oriented language as well, however one needs to pay attention to provide all necessary arguments manually - usually an OOP language requires the first argument to represent this or self and only then pass in the additional arguments. It may be easier to use Message.createInvoke(int) message which is more suitable for object oriented languages and handles (if supported) the arguments manipulation automatically.

        All messages created by this method are equal to each other regardless of the value of argumentsLength.

        Parameters:
        argumentsLength - number of parameters to pass to the target
        Returns:
        execute message
        Since:
        0.8 or earlier

      • createInvoke

        public static Message createInvoke(int argumentsLength)
        Creates an object oriented execute message. Unlike Message.createExecute(int) the receiver of the message isn't the actual function to invoke, but an object. The object has the function as a field, or as a field of its class, or whatever is appropriate for an object oriented language.

        Languages that don't support object oriented semantics do not and should not implement this message. When the invoke message isn't supported, the caller is expected to fall back into following basic operations:

        • sending Message.READ message to access the field
        • verify the result Message.IS_EXECUTABLE, if so continue by
        • sending execute message

        The last step is problematic, as it is not clear whether to pass just the execution arguments, or prefix them with the original receiver (aka this or self). Object oriented languages would in general welcome obtaining the receiving object as first argument, non-object languages like C would get confused by doing so. However it is not possible for the caller to find out what language one is sending message to - only the set of supported messages is known. As a result it is recommended for object oriented languages to support the Message.createInvoke(int) message and handle the semantics the way it is natural to them. Languages like C shouldn't implement Message.createInvoke(int) and just support primitive operations like Message.createExecute(int) and Message.READ.

        When accessing a method of an object in an object oriented manner, one is supposed to send the Message.createInvoke(int) message first. Only when that fails, fallback to non-object oriented workflow with Message.createExecute(int). Imagine there is a Java class with add method and its instance: 

         public class Arith {
    public double add(double a, double b) {
      return a + b;
    }
 }
 Arith obj = new Arith();

        If the object does not support the INVOKE message, an UnsupportedMessageException has to be thrown. If the object does not allow invoking a member with the given identifier, an UnknownIdentifierException has to be thrown. If the caller provides a wrong number of arguments, an ArityException has to be thrown. If one of the provided argument values has an unsupported type, an UnsupportedTypeException has to be thrown.

        To access obj's add method one should use: 

         try {
   ForeignAccess.sendInvoke(
     Message.createInvoke(2).Message.createNode(),  obj, "add", valueOfA, valueOfB
   );
 } catch (IllegalArgumentException ex) {
   // access the language via Message.createExecute(int)
 }
        The valueOfA and valueOfB should be double or Double or at least be unboxable to such type.

        All messages created by this method are equal to each other regardless of the value of argumentsLength. The expected behavior of this message is to perform Message.READ first and on the result invoke Message.createExecute(int).

        Parameters:
        argumentsLength - number of parameters to pass to the target
        Returns:
        message combining read & execute messages tailored for use with object oriented languages
        Since:
        0.8 or earlier

      • createNew

        public static Message createNew(int argumentsLength)
        Creates an allocation message. All messages created by this method are equal to each other regardless of the value of argumentsLength. The expected behavior of this message is to allocate a new instance of the receiver and then perform its constructor with appropriate number of arguments.

        If the object does not support the NEW message, an UnsupportedMessageException has to be thrown. If the caller provides a wrong number of arguments, an ArityException has to be thrown. If one of the provided argument values has an unsupported type, an UnsupportedTypeException has to be thrown.

        Parameters:
        argumentsLength - number of parameters to pass to the target
        Returns:
        new instance message
        Since:
        0.8 or earlier

      • equals

        public abstract boolean equals(Object message)
        Compares types of two messages. Messages are encouraged to implement this method. All standard ones (Message.IS_NULL, Message.READ, etc.) do so. Messages obtained via the same method are equal, messages obtained by different methods or fields are not.
        Overrides:
        equals in class Object
        Parameters:
        message - the object to compare to
        Returns:
        true, if the structure of the message is that same as of this one.
        Since:
        0.8 or earlier

      • hashCode

        public abstract int hashCode()
        When re-implementing Message.equals(java.lang.Object), it is generally recommended to also implement hashCode().
        Overrides:
        hashCode in class Object
        Returns:
        hash code
        Since:
        0.8 or earlier

      • createNode

        public final Node createNode()
        Creates an AST node for this message. The node can be inserted into AST of your language and will handle communication with the foreign language.
        Returns:
        node to be inserted into your AST and passed back to ForeignAccess.send(com.oracle.truffle.api.nodes.Node, com.oracle.truffle.api.interop.TruffleObject, java.lang.Object...) method.
        Since:
        0.8 or earlier

      • toString

        public static String toString(Message message)
        Converts the message into canonical string representation. The converted string can be stored, persisted, transfered and later passed to Message.valueOf(java.lang.String) to construct the message again.
        Parameters:
        message - the message to convert
        Returns:
        canonical string representation
        Since:
        0.9

      • valueOf

        public static Message valueOf(String messageId)
        Converts string representation into real message. If the string was obtained by Message.toString(com.oracle.truffle.api.interop.Message) method, it is guaranteed to be successfully recognized (if the classpath of the system remains the same).
        Parameters:
        messageId - canonical string representation of a message
        Returns:
        the message
        Throws:
        IllegalArgumentException - if the string does not represent known message
        Since:
        0.9
